2009/9/8 Colin Green <colin.green1@...>:

> One warning here, the centroid calculation
> changes for different distance metrics. For Euclidean distance we take
> the mean, for Manhattan we take the median value - I'm attempting to
> explain this as part of my speciation overview in the above URL.

You can forget this comment. In the various references and papers I've
found regarding k-means and Manhatten distance there seems to be a lot
of confusion about what is trying to be achieved. If we want to choose
a centroid that minimizes the sum of squared distance from the
centroid then the mean centroid is correct for both Euclidean and
Manhattan distance - and I think for *all* norms (Minkowski distance).
So this is effectively minimizing squared error or variance.

If we calculate the median centroid then strictly speaking that is
k-medians clustering, and that minimizes the sum of distance to the
centroid, not squared distance. This is irregardless of the distance
metric.

As a side note using the median centroid can be used to handle outlier
points better than the mean centroid, in the same way that calculating
a median value of some variable helps alleviate the bias from any
large outlier values.

Colin
